betterquesting:10.desc:8:
The Overworld Drill breaks the formula somewhat, by ultalizing a secondary item. Overworld Drill "missions" are split into different biomes, determined by circuit number. Each mission contains its relevant wood, saplings, relevant plants, and a flower color.

While most of the overworld drill missions are just for cosmetic purposes, you will need to launch at least one drill to the plains biome, to get sugarcane. As well as being an easier method of paper, you will need sugarcane to make PE.

A coke oven can be used to make charcoal out of wood without the need of furance fuel. It also has the very helpful side product of creosote, which can be used to make treated wood, which in turn can be used to make a primitive water pump. Creosote can also be used to make lube, which will have a use in the future.
Thankfully, some of the items you had before the fall didn't get destoryed. The patch of dirt that you landed on can be reformed into dirt that is plantable. Use that to get some wood going.

By crafting an ex nihilo hammer, you can mine the blocks that make up this land into cobblestone. On top of cobblestone being useful as is, you can also mine the cobblestone to get gravel, which in turn can be mined into sand and dust.

A barrel has two main uses:

1. You can turn organic matter into dirt by placing it inside the barrel. Your best option currently is saplings.

2. If you place a bucket of water inside, followed by a block of dust, it will turn into clay, this latter one will be a bit more important for the time being.

Come on, you know how a furnace works.

Use it to make some charcoal (you can smelt wood into charcoal).
Use the aforementioned method to make some clay. Clay will be used to smelt some bricks, and to make some brick dust with the aid of a hammer.
Using some brick blocks and a furance, you can repair that broken boiler into a working steam boiler

Don't worry, you dont have to make a PBF. 

Use a brick mold to compress the dust into ingots.

The PBF bricks will be used to make your first drill base.

Fluid pipes can be used to transport fluids, and likewise for item pipes. You can use these pipes to move fluids into and out of your steam generator. CEu pipes work like 5u pipes, and don't look ugly as well.

Pipes will also be used to craft the tier one drill base.

betterquesting:10.name:8: Tier one drill base + T1 drill
betterquesting:10.desc:8: Drills are your primary method to get resources in this world. Drills, well, drill, your resouces up. Drills require a base to launch them, and a drill will "belong" to a base (eg you can only launch tier one and two drills on a tier one base). A single drill doesnt bring back many resources on it's own, but it's power is in numbers. LV and above base, along with the ablity to overclock, possess a (WIP) mechanic that rewards constant usage. While you can not overclock steam, it's drills are fairly cheap to make, so I would recomend making a few more while you are at it.
Take some of those iron ingots, turn it into a mortar. You can use that mortar to turn some tin and copper into copper, and thus into bronze.

Now with a source of bronze, you can get to work making steam machines.

Most of the recipes in steam machines are fairly obvious (eg the macerator macerates), but I will point out changed or new recipes.

By pressurizing some charcoal, you can make diamonds out of it!
Use these diamonds to make a macerator, and to generally upgrade your tools.

The PBF is slow and boring, so you decided to use something that is slightly less slow. The alloy smelter recipe is somewhat inefficient, but it works well enough for now.

You can also use it to upgrade your steam machines into highpressure steam machines, which doubles their speed.

You can choose to use higher tier ingots while making pistons, which will change how many pistons you will get per craft. For example, using steel instead of iron or bronze will double how many pistons you get.

Regardless if you choose to invest in that, you will still need pistons to craft various machines.

The tier two drill also runs on steam, and is used to bring back iron at a higher rate, as well as coal and sulfur, which are used in the creation of your first ciruits.

It also brings back lead.

Don't use that coal to make torches!

Rather, grind it into a dust so you can make some circuits with it!

Wood pulp can be compressed into chad, which inturn can be compressed into paper.

Yes, the quest title is a pun.
By smashing and reforming some glass, you can make some glass tubes.

Time to put all of that wood to good use! You can extract rubber pulp from rubber tree wood, which can then been combined with sulfur in an alloy smelter to make rubber, which is used to make cables

As for the rubber pulp, it is used in the creation of your first circuit board, as well as in some other parts of the first circuit.

A crucible can be used to make lava, and works in a similar way to making dirt. Remeber that you have to place a heat generating object, such as a torch, under the crucible to make lava, with hotter things being faster. (Lava works much faster than a torch)

With a rock breaker, you can generate cobblestone from thin air! If you really wanted to go all out, you could chain it into some forge hammers to hammer it into whatever resource you need it to be, such as sand or dust.

The rock breaker supports some other blocks as well, so you could set it to generate stone instead, to skip smelting it.

If standard coal boilers are not your thing, you do have some other options of making steam. Lava boilers work faster than coal boilers, but require lava in their production. You could also take advantage of the shaft of light at spawn to use solar boilers to generate free steam. Later on, multiblock options for steam generation also unlock, so keep an eye out for those.

All of these methods can be upgraded to high pressure once you get steel.

Put 'em all together, and you get yourself your first LV circuit!

I would recommend crafting a few these at once while your at it.
(go over the tools and their uses)

It's overwheming.

Craft your first LV turbine.

ยง1ยง1TODO: have overview of wires, cable loss and amps

If you are, remeber that machines that use RF can connect to gregtech wires, and that the power will automatically convert into RF!

For progressive automation machines to work, you need to craft a RF engine, and place it in the machine's fuel slot.
No Description

Now with ores! 

Ores can be futher processed to give the player more resources, or even some resources can the be onlu  obtained with ore processing.
As previously brought up, LV and above bases, along with the ablity to overclock, possess a (WIP) mechanic that rewards constant usage.

yeah

(go over the new machines and their uses)

betterquesting:10.name:8: I want my connected storage and I want it NOW!
betterquesting:10.desc:8: If you absolutely need connected storage asap, you have an option. There is a somewhat neutered version of Simple storage network that only requires bronze and steel related materials. While it does lack output out of it's "network", it still retains the ability to have a crafting grid built into your system, which can help with microcrafting monotony.
Lube can be made in a few ways, the main two currently being from creosote and seed oil. Just note that the slow production of creosote may be a bottleneck, so it may be worth parallelizing it.

Drilling fluid is made from lube. 

Tip: It may be worth splitting the output from whatever machine is making into two; One as a tank to hold your lube, and the other is a chemical reactor, to be futher processed into drilling fluid.

They store fluids, if you havent made some by this point, you really should.

There are also wooden tanks, ideal for holding large amounts of water.

These buggers can be a bit expensive to craft, so make sure you have a handle on your resources.

Anyways, the tier four drill brings back:

The electric blast furance is, and has been a mainstay of gregtech, and this is no different. 

Use the nickel from the tier four drill to make some cupronickel, which will be your first EBF coils.

Tip: the EBF steel recipe is much cheaper, and takes less time.
Use your EBF to make some boules, then cut them in a cutting saw. These wafers will be used to make your first tier two circuits.
Gallium can be obtained by electrolyzing your newfound sphalerite.

Silicon can be obtained by electrolyzing your newfound soapstone. Silicon has various uses, such as being a major part of boules.

Later on, silicon can be obtained easier from electroyzing clay dust, and soapstone can be put towards making magnesium, or just making lube at a better ratio.
TBD
Just like that, you're already knocking on the door of MV!

These squares  (and it's relatives) will be used in a decent number of circuits from here on out.

Crafting them manually will require on, but later one, once you get silver, you can save resources by crafting them in a assember.

Diodes can be made with glass, but PE can be used to double the output of circuits, though it is not required just yet.

Using both PE and annealed copper will give you 8 per craft.

Now with MV machinary at your disposal, you can start making new stuff, and make old stuff faster!

Your first order of business aught to be making an electrolyzer, so you can get aluminum much easier.

The Biome Drill breaks the formula somewhat, by ultalizing a secondary item. Overworld Drill "missions" are split into different biomes, determined by circuit number. Each mission contains its relevant wood, saplings, relevant plants, and a flower color.

While most of the biome drill missions are just for cosmetic purposes (eg access to resouces to build with), you will need to launch at least one drill to the swamp biome, to get sugarcane. As well as being an easier method of paper, you will need sugarcane to make PE. As well as that, consider launching a biome drill to the plains biome to get seeds. Seeds can be used to make seed oil.

(Exposition goes here)

The two water buckets are to be replaced with a NC watergen once the NC CEu confict crash is fixed.

Aluminum ingots are made in an EBF, and are used to make MV machines.

Tip: Use two LV input hatches to overclock your EBF to MV.

Whats better than inf water? 

Water that generates even faster, of course!

Welcome to the underground.

Your top priority is to get some steam power going, so you can start mining up your first resources.
Now with your first drill base and steam power, you can start mining some resources and making some steam machines to help push into LV.

Finally, power! 

This chapter covers LV and MV. LV and early MV are relativly unmodified in terms of recipes, to aid the player in getting infastructure up.
